text: bug collecting is a fine hobby but it's
not something that pilots want to do on
the job bugs that accumulate on
airplanes increased drag and reduce fuel
efficiency that's why a team of NASA
researchers have developed new coatings
to help plane wings shed bug guts during
flight which they tested this spring in
Shreveport Louisiana
here's NASA senior scientist Emily
co-chief if you have bugs accumulating
what it does is it it causes the airflow
to trip from aerodynamic to turbulent
what we want to do is test to see if the
coatings that we developed actually
reduce the number of bug strikes but
what benefit could there be in sloughing
off bug splatters there are typically
only a few centimeters in diameter you
could gain Oh on the order of five to
six percent in savings of fuel after
testing nearly 200 coatings in the lab
using a bug cannon to launch living
fruit flies at sample surfaces the team
flew a handful of its best candidates on
Boeing's eco demonstrator 757 aircraft
we designed the test so that half of the
panels are untreated and half of them
have the surfaces that we are flying and
so what we do is have several takeoffs
and landings because those sort of parts
of the flight profile where you actually
accumulate bugs the researchers found
that their coatings were capable of
reducing accumulated bug juice by about
40% NASA isn't disclosing the exact
composition of the coatings yet but that
information will be released the agency
says for now gog offers a few clues
about the secret to the new surfaces
success well we came up with was a
combination of chemical design of the
decoding and topographical roughness
like what you see in lotus leaves
that prevents water from sticking so it
becomes chemistry plus topography rather
than just chemistry for chemical and
engineering news this is Matt Davenport
